Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will help address the urgent need for a new engineering workforce. Middle school students will be entering a workforce that is increasingly global. They will need not only technical skills but also global competencies including: the ability to investigate the world, recognize perspectives, communicate ideas, and take action. This model integrates engineering with global competencies and will provide new knowledge about how this type of learning experience impacts students and educators.

This project builds on the success of the previous Design Squad project funded by NSF and developed by WGBH, which has implemented a national model for engineering education for middle school youth. This project expands the model internationally, connecting U.S. based youth with those in Southern Africa (including South Africa, Botswana, and Swaziland). The project partners are FHI 360, a non-profit organization in 60 countries around the world that helps build capacity for improving lives. They will facilitate the implementation of the afterschool programs in Southern Africa . The US dissemination partners include Promise Neighborhoods Institute, Middle Start, Every Hour Counts, and the National Girls Collaborative Project. Project deliverables include a global engineering curriculum; a web platform with videos, games, activities; an afterschool Club Guide; and a Community of Practice for informal engineering educators.

A knowledge building component will provide new evidence on how high quality accessible resources and strategies can impact students' development of global competencies and engineering skills to solve real world problems. An iterative approach will be used to develop the resources including the global engineering afterschool curriculum, Club guide, and other components. The methodology uses a continuous cycle of improvement including: assess/design, test/ implement, synthesize/reflect, and utilize/disseminate. The Summative Evaluation will generate evidence about whether and how this kind of collaborative work builds children's understanding of engineering, motivation to participate, and confidence in taking informed action on behalf of pressing global problems. This will contribute to a larger body of work about whether and how engaging with global, collaborative engineering problems leads to greater self-efficacy for children with very different backgrounds, experiences, and opportunities. This project will add new knowledge about how the well-honed Design Squad model in the U.S. can be expanded with a global context and global partners. This proposal was co-funded by EHR/DRL, Engineering/EEC, and International Science and Engineering.

During the project period approximately 125,000 children in the US and 5000 children in southern Africa will be reached. In the long term, with the continued global access to the resources, the reach will potentially be in the millions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Design Squad Global (DSG) was a digital hub and outreach initiative that created new opportunities to empower middle school youth to solve real-world problems and understand the impact of engineering in a global context. Through a collaboration with the global development organization FHI 360, the project built on Design Squad’s well-honed model for engineering education while using a range of methods to research the challenges and infrastructure needed to inspire and prepare young, globally competent engineers in afterschool programs, both in the U.S. and internationally.  

 

Major outcomes were the development of:

 

  • A Club Guide, with embedded professional development videos, that provided support for implementing the model and prepares afterschool educators to skillfully facilitate collaborative, hands-on engineering activities

Using the Club Guide, in Design Squad Global (DSG) clubs, kids ages 10-13 in out-of-school time programs around the world explored engineering through fun-packed, high energy, hands-on activities, such as designing and building an emergency shelter or a structure that can withstand an earthquake. Through DSG, kids also got a special opportunity: the chance to work alongside a partner club from another country. Partner clubs shared their experiences by exchanging design ideas, photos, and videos. Along the way, they developed their global competency by learning more about each other’s cultures, communities, and lives. Since the launch of this outreach project in October 2016, 511 clubs have participated from 125 cities in 37 states and 40 countries reaching 6,108 kids. Countries included the US, Jordan, Malawi, Botswana, South Africa, Swaziland, Costa Rica, Brazil, Vietnam, Australia, Singapore, Liberia, Haiti, Cambodia, China, Kenya, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, Ghana, Ukraine, Peru, Canada, Germany, Bolivia, Paraguay, France, Romania, Bulgaria, India, Lesotho, South Korea, Burma, Italy, Greece, and Turkey.

 

  • A model for the co-creation of engineering curricula by educators and students, developed through an iterative design process informed by research

As a result of a careful, iterative development process—a pre-pilot, and two pilot rounds of implementation—the DSG model was significantly improved to establish its effectiveness to support broad global dissemination, including the creation of a framework that articulated how educators can promote the abilities needed by students to investigate another culture, take on multiple perspectives, and communicate their ideas.

 

The research findings revealed important lessons about the challenges, infrastructure, and support needed for an afterschool program to inspire and prepare a cohort of young, globally competent engineers in the U.S. and internationally. The partnership between clubs, and how to best support communications and collaboration between Club Leaders, was an important area of learning for DSG. Communication was very challenging, especially at the beginning, and schedule matching/ synchronization challenges hindered timely communications between partner Club Leaders. This led to some clear recommendations for increased ramp-up time, including an opportunity for Club Leaders to get to know each other, and for giving clubs some options in terms of the intensity of the partnership exchanges expected. Providing more structured templates for partnership exchanges was also a strong recommendation after the first round of implementation. Despite the challenges, the idea of the partnership was consistently exciting to both Club Leaders and students, and there was clear motivation to make the partnerships work. The kids demanded more exchanges with their partner club, and were especially interested in increased intercultural communication, in addition to the engineering-based exchanges.

 

  • A web platform—refreshed weekly with challenges, videos, games, and activities—that enabled students to share ideas with peers from different geographic locations 

Design Squad website was rebranded as Design Squad Global, and regularly updated with new videos, blog posts on engineering and inventing, submissions to our online community, Global Challenges, and Top Builder Challenges, all of which promoted engineering within a global context. We also produced a new interactive map feature called “Global Kids” that let kids see designs submitted from other youth around the world.

 

  • Summative evaluation to assess intended impacts with U.S. and international youth and educators 

DSG successfully taught middle school-aged children in the US and abroad about engineering, including important science concepts, such as structural integrity. DSG also had a positive impact on children’s ability to design a solution to a real-world problem and on their interest in participating in more engineering activities in the future. DSG was also successful in encouraging children to want to help people in other countries solve problems in their communities. With respect to DSG club leaders, the evaluation found strong evidence that the DSG helped leaders feel comfortable leading engineering activities.

 

The results of an outreach partner survey demonstrated that DSG reached a very diverse audience. More than one-third of the communities served were Hispanic, Latino/a, or Spanish (37%), 31% were white, and 21% were Black or African-American. Most of the audiences served by clubs were low income (55%), followed by medium (27%), and high-income audiences (18%).
